sub_title: My ambition is to gain a degree of humility at the School of Life
summary:
I am a professional with a background in teaching, research and advocacy especially in the field of International Development, where my specific interests range across the following: 
- genocide and post-genocide Rwandan politics 
- Conflict and peace in the Great Lakes regions
- Media studies especially radio and visual arts
- Non-surveillance and Undocumented people in Europe 
- Networks of pro-asylum advocates 

My goals are to find work that combines my interest in research and advocacy with ways of organising and creative work to create art that aims to promote social and economic justice goals within localities at risk of polarisation and violence. This implies work within neighbourhoods in Western Europe, through forms of 'doorstep politics', in actions to defend rights of vulnerable people, citizens and others, on a daily basis.

Specialties: Intersted in capacitation of others, more than ambitions of my own. Deriving pleasure from others' positive learning. On-line role play simulations are a method of teaching that I have used in several different settings (see Roni Linser on Linkedin for an example of a good provider).

treasury_media.title: Innovative methods of teaching at ISS
treasury_media.description: Uploaded by issmedia on 2012-12-13. Produced by Hani Shehada, a talented young Palestinian film maker and ISS graduate. Describes the Rwanda on-line role play simulation that we run after the first half of the video. The film is introduced by the charming and positive former Deputy Rector of ISS, Jos Mooij, who sadly passed away in late February 2013.  She was instrumental in encouraging staff to innovate in their teaching methods.

profile_positions.description:
2014-2016 Convenor of SJP (Human Rights, Gender and Conflict: Social Justice Perspectives) a Masters major with around 30-40 students per annum.  

2012, 2013, 2016 Scholas award for Best Teachers (one of several each year). 

Convenor for 2010-12 of Conflict, Reconstruction and Human Security specialisation on the Development Masters of ISS.  This specialisation was then merged with Human Rights and the Gender specialisations to form a new Major program in SJP (Social Justice) 

I look forward to ISS continuing to inspire students and staff in future, as an institution that can survive these hard times, and still flourish. Academic autonomy for students and staff is vital for this purpose, so is the well-being of all staff, including support staff, academics and management, from the contracted-out cleaning staff up to the senior management.  The biggest challenge remains (always) to actually manage to practice what we preach.
profile_positions.title: Formerly Assistant Professor in Development and Social Justice (Retired)

profile_positions.description: I teach and do research in human rights, conflict and peace studies, and in social justice broadly defined. Besides working on the African Great Lakes region, and especially researching post-genocide politics in Rwanda, together with Veronika Goussatchenko of ISS, I also manage a Nuffic-funded NICHE Capacity Building project in Uganda, in partnership with the Nsamizi Training Institute for Social Development. This was started by my former ISS colleague Nicholas Awortwi. My main research intersets are described in the summary below.
profile_positions.title: Assistant Professor

profile_positions.description: The Centre for Development Studies at Swansea University (formerly University of Wales, Swansea) was opened some time in the 1960s. It was one of the first places to offer an undergraduate degree in (international) Development Studies. There were several  Masters programs, among the best-known being Social Development Planning and Management. In their wisdom, the University management decided to run CDS down from 2003, first closing the undergraduate program, and then shutting the Centre it completely by 2010, despite continuing health recruitment into the Masters. The last batch of Masters students graduated in 2010.  The closure of CDS was resisted through a long campaign, and the decision to shut it, without any clear rationale, has proven a loss to Wales, and to the field of International Development Studies. A panel devoted to the history of CDS was organised by Chris Gerry at the DSA Annual conference in November 2010.
